271.text:
>> David Ferriero: Good afternoon. I'm David
Ferriero, Archivist of the United States.

275.text:
It's a pleasure to welcome you here to the
McGowan Theater. For those of you who are

280.text:
with us physically and for those of you who
are joining us on our YouTube Channel, welcome.

287.text:
Today we will hear about one of the country's
most famous military men, General George Armstrong

293.text:
Custer from T.J. Stiles most recent book,
"Custer's Trials: A Life on the Frontier of

299.text:
a New America." And T.J. will be signing after
he speaks today. General Custer is remembered

308.text:
best for his defeat, a decisive one, by Native-Americans
at the Battle of Little Bighorn in 1876, popularly

317.text:
known as Custer's last stand. But there is
so much more to the Custer story than Bighorn.

324.text:
Before we hear about that, I'd like to tell
you about a couple of programs that are coming

327.text:
up soon here in this theater. Monday, September
7 at 7:00 we'll present a program to observe

334.text:
the 150th anniversary of the 13th Amendment
which banned slavery throughout the United

339.text:
States. Jeffrey Rosen, President of the National
Constitution Center, will lead a discussion

345.text:
of the amendment's impact with a panel that
includes a member of Congress, a federal judge,

350.text:
a journalist, and several history professors.
Next Wednesday, December 9 at noon, we'll

357.text:
offer a program entitled "Embassy to the Eastern
Courts: America's Secret First Pivot Toward

364.text:
Asia, 1832-1837". The author Andrew Jampoler
will tell how President Jackson looked for

373.text:
new trading partners before being locked out
of traditional markets in Europe and the Caribbean

379.text:
after the Napoleonic War turned to Asia. A
book signing will follow that program.

385.text:
Today's guest is prize-winning author T.J.
Stiles. It's a particular pleasure for me

391.text:
to be welcoming T.J. back to the National
Archives where he mined the records researching

397.text:
this new book. I often cite T.J. as an example
of how important serious researchers are to

406.text:
institutions like this. Scholars who mine
the collections in their research and help

412.text:
us better understand what is in our holdings
in the generation of new scholarship. And

416.text:
for me this new book completes a trifecta.
T.J. researched his first book, "Jesse James,"

424.text:
at Duke University where I was the university
librarian. That book won the Ambassador Book

431.text:
Award and the Peter Seeburg Award for Civil
War Scholarship. His next book, "The First

437.text:
Tycoon: The Epic Life of Cornelius Vanderbilt,"
which received the 2010 Pulitzer Prize, T.J.

444.text:
researched as a fellow at the Cullman Center
at the New York Public Library where I was

449.text:
the Director of Libraries. And now the Custer
book which draws on many different record

459.text:
groups across the National Archives facilities.
I'm so proud of the role that my three institutions

465.text:
have played in T.J.'s scholarship.
The reviews of this book have been over the

471.text:
top. Has there been a bad review?
>> T.J. Stiles: I wouldn't say over the top.

475.text:
>> David Ferriero: I would. [Laughter] Described
as a biography of stunning richness, captivating,

483.text:
epic, ambitious, bursting at the seams. My
favorite is from a publication named "Biography"

492.text:
which recently renamed "Signature." What's
remarkable about the Custer that emerges in

499.text:
"Custer's Trials" is how both his internal
and external states are. For every dichotomy

505.text:
of an America in flux that his public persona
enlightens, there is also a deeply seeded

513.text:
personal anxiety that racked Custer. Because
of this re-emerges as one of those too rare

520.text:
literary characters whose internal and external
states, are unified in what they tell us about

528.text:
a time in history and the consequences that
befall a person who tried to project himself

534.text:
into another world.
Please welcome my friend T.J. Stiles.

542.text:
>> [Applause]
>> T.J. Stiles: Thank you very much. It's

546.text:
a real honor and a pleasure to be here. As
the National Archivist as just said, we have

554.text:
known each other for a number of years. I
am immensely pleased that he's in charge of

560.text:
the National Archives. He's a real professional.
It's a delight to be here.

567.text:
I want to start straight off with a letter
which was written on October 12, 1865, by

578.text:
Moses P. Hanson. Hanson was the surgeon of
the 2P the Wisconsin Cavalry Regiment, on

590.text:
occupation duty after the end of the Civil
War. He wrote of a case that he had investigated

597.text:
personally and knew the facts of.
It had happened not 48 hours since, not two

604.text:
days previously. On October 10, two days before
he wrote the letter, a 9-year-old girl somehow

611.text:
crossed 23 miles of Texas countryside from
a plantation into the town of Hempstead where

619.text:
Hanson was posted. She had been held in slavery
all of her life. And this was now three months

627.text:
after Juneteenth, the declaration of the Emancipation
Proclamation in Texas which had not been occupied

633.text:
by Union troops during the war itself yet
she had still been held in de facto slavery.

640.text:
And like so many African American families,
hers had been divided by slavery. Her mother,

646.text:
however, was just 23 miles away, an enormous
distance for a 9-year-old girl but still within

653.text:
reachable distance, living with a white woman,
a Mrs.Godie, [phonetic] who lived in this

657.text:
village of Hempstead. So she crossed that
distance somehow and managed to find her mother

663.text:
and reunite with her in Mrs. Godie's house.
Soon afterwards, a 13-year-old boy showed

670.text:
up. His name was Willis Chambers. He was the
son of the owners of the plantation and the

677.text:
people who had considered themselves the young
girl's owner. He declared, as Hanson wrote,

684.text:
that he had gotten orders from his mother
to bring her, the girl, out of Hempstead or

691.text:
kill her. She refused to let go of her mother.
He literally had to pry her off her mother

697.text:
and tied her hands behind her back. Quote,
he then tied her hands behind her back and

704.text:
tied a rope around her waist, pulled her out,
and tied her to a ring in his saddle, mounted,

710.text:
and put spurs to the horse. As he dragged
the girl, she fell down. Then the horse reacted

718.text:
to her falling by kicking her. And before
they had gotten very far, he cut her loose,

723.text:
quote, a mass of broken flesh and bones, dead.
Now, the mother of this girl complained to

730.text:
the Army Provost Marshal who was in Hempstead,
who was in charge of the application of law

736.text:
and order in a military district. Quote, he
refused to mettle, Hanson wrote. She then

743.text:
went to General Custer and he sent to arrest
the boy. Major General George Armstrong Custer,

751.text:
Major General of U.S. Volunteers, who was
the commanding general in Hempstead, who was

756.text:
now in charge of administering this area of
Texas, had to decide what to do with this

762.text:
boy who openly admitted having killed this
9-year-old girl.

766.text:
Now, Custer is one of the most controversial
figures in American history. People love him

773.text:
and they hate him. These days they tend to
hate him more than love him. He was, in fact,

778.text:
notorious, as well as a celebrity, during
his own lifetime. But whether you love Custer

784.text:
or hate him or have no particular opinion,
we all envision him in a particular way, usually

791.text:
alone on a hill top surrounded by his dead
soldiers as Cheyenne and other warriors circle

797.text:
around him as he fires off his last bullet
and is slaughtered along with more than 200

803.text:
of his troops.
This Custer is the one that lives in our imagination.

808.text:
He is a man of the West. He is a man who is
eternally fighting Native-Americans. He's

813.text:
someone who we can't really imagine anywhere
else. Certainly we don't imagine him in an

821.text:
administrative role, not on a horse, not leading
a charge into battle, but rather sitting behind

829.text:
a desk administering justice, deciding a case
of life and death in the aftermath of slavery

837.text:
in Texas.
This is a letter that I found in the National

841.text:
Archives by doing something that historians
should do, biographers should do, which is

847.text:
to try to think broadly, to try to go to collections
that aren't obvious. Custer is one of the

854.text:
most researched people in American history.
And I respect that research. There are people

859.text:
who have never published a thing who know
details about Custer's life that I don't know.

864.text:
So it's a subject to be approached with humility.
It's not something that I want to make exaggerated

869.text:
claims about when it comes to my knowing more
than anyone else or having discovered things

874.text:
no one had seen before. And yet by approaching
it with a different set of interests, a different

881.text:
set of priorities, I tried to put together
a picture of Custer's life and his significance

888.text:
and his meaning for Americans at the time
before he got to the Little Bighorn, before

894.text:
that enormous sunrises over his life and blinds
us to everything that came before that stunning

901.text:
death of his, which was, indeed, significant.
Why was it that Custer was a celebrity before

907.text:
he got there? Why was it that he was notorious
before he got there? What was the meaning

912.text:
that Americans saw in him before he took on
the meanings that we put upon him? This was

917.text:
the mission that I set for myself in writing
this biography of Custer. And by going outside

924.text:
of the usual collections that people consult,
I began to put that picture together.

930.text:
So here we have Custer as seen in a letter,
the unregistered letters sent to the assistant

937.text:
commissioner of the Bureau of -- refugees,
freed men and abandoned lands, the Freedmen's

944.text:
Bureau. It's not a place people usually look
for information about Custer. And yet, if

949.text:
we look at his life, we find that race, slavery,
emancipation, and civil rights runs through

956.text:
his life, a major theme not only in his public
role but in the way he envisioned the world

962.text:
and in his private relationships.
There's another aspect to Custer as well,

967.text:
one that's a little bit more familiar. That's
Custer as the Army officer. And I want to

972.text:
come back to this case in a moment but first
I'm going to go back to other records from

977.text:
the National Archives that illuminate Custer.
And many of these are very well-known. He

982.text:
was a young boy from a poor background in
Ohio who went off to West Point, very lucky

988.text:
he got an appointment to West Point. There,
as one of his classmates said, when he realized

994.text:
he could not lead the class academically,
he decided to support it by providing a solid

999.text:
base. He graduated last in his class but first
in demerits.

1006.text:
And what does that mean? Again, this is something
I have to do. I have to try to understand

1011.text:
the human meaning, the interior state, that's
reflected in the outer actions. All of those

1016.text:
demerits are a reflection of his acting out,
of his performing for an audience and that

1023.text:
audience are his fellow cadets, trying to
project an image of himself. This is an important

1029.text:
fact about Custer, something to understand
but also see passed, he was always telling

1035.text:
stories about himself. He was telling stories
to an audience. And he was also telling those

1041.text:
stories to himself. That this ego, this grand
performative nature, his elaborate costume

1047.text:
he wore into battle, the costumes he adopted
when he went west, when he wore buckskin instead

1053.text:
of a black velvet uniform as he had during
the war, this is telling a story to the public

1058.text:
and one for himself that he's not that obscure
boy that no one from nowhere; that, in fact

1066.text:
he's someone who is great, who is performing
on a historical stage, a man who is an antebellum,

1074.text:
romantic hero. That's the story he's telling
an d one he is always trying to tell himself

1077.text:
he wants to be. So he performs for an audience.
Well, he graduates from West Point. And he's

1080.text:
still performing for that audience. He hasn't
been assigned a regular post in the Army yet.

1083.text:
And just days after graduating he is the commander
of the guard for the Army encampment, the

1088.text:
training encampment for the cadets as they
train in the summer. An upper classman starts

1094.text:
a fistfight with an underclassman. Custer
is in charge. He's captain of the guard. He's

1099.text:
supposed to arrest them. An Army can't function
with the soldiers fist fighting with each

1104.text:
other at will. And instead he says, stand
back, boys, let them have a fair fight. Now

1110.text:
aday that would be handled administratively
but this was something he was court martialed

1114.text:
for, convicted. But Custer's luck came in.
Something saved him again and again. The Civil

1120.text:
War broke out. He's terribly fearful he'll
miss the entire thing. So he pleads for mercy,

1126.text:
admits his guilty, pleads for mercy. The court
martial convicts him but they let him go off

1132.text:
to war.
There he finds a new audience. He's performing

1137.text:
now for his superiors. He finds a mission.
And suddenly the miscreative West Point begins

1144.text:
to perform extremely well. And there's something
charming about him, something very hard to

1148.text:
capture in the documents. He's got charisma.
And his superiors are susceptible to it. So

1155.text:
during the campaign, he's actually plucked
from obscurity when he performs very well,

1161.text:
taking part in the raid on Confederate position,
that comes to the attention of General McClellan,

1167.text:
puts him on the staff. Now Custer is performing
for General McClellan. He performs very well.

1173.text:
Interestingly, he worships McClellan, a notoriously
conservative general politically and in military

1180.text:
operations. Custer worships this man who is
so accomplished and so esteemed even though

1187.text:
his own personality is so different. He's
volunteering to go off on raids. He wants

1192.text:
to win in a way that McClellan doesn't. That's
what saves him when McClellan falls, the fact

1198.text:
that he's a committed soldier who wants to
win.

1201.text:
But the other thing that saves him is not
just his merit. It's the fact that he's trying

1205.text:
to find a new patron. Remember, the Civil
War was not fought primarily by the regular

1211.text:
Army but by an organization that was created
for the duration of the war, the U.S. Volunteers.

1218.text:
And this is a very political Army with regiments
raised by the states, with regimental officers

1222.text:
appointed by governors. It's very much reflects
antebellum America, a world of personal connections,

1229.text:
where there's very few large institutions.
Lincoln himself was a self-taught lawyer.

1235.text:
Before the end of the 19th Century, it's unimaginable
to think of a self-taught lawyer representing

1239.text:
the largest corporations in America as Lincoln
had. And this is the world, though, that Custer

1246.text:
came out of.
So he's in the Army, one of the first great

1251.text:
institutions of the upcoming America, the
organizational society. But he's operating

1257.text:
very much as a man of the past, looking for
those personal patrons. Still current. It's

1261.text:
not past yet. But this is a world that is
not looking to the future but rather one that

1267.text:
reflects an older America. And he finds a
new patron. The patron becomes the commander

1273.text:
of the cavalry corps of the Army of the Potomac.
When the North is invaded, Custer's -- the

1280.text:
general who picks Custer for his staff gets
a chance to appoint new brigade commanders.

1285.text:
He takes this 23-year-old cadet -- lieutenant,
who graduated last in his class and makes

1292.text:
him a brigadier general.
And what happens? Custer performs exceptionally

1297.text:
well. He goes straight -- practically straight
to the battle of Gettysburg. His men see him

1301.text:
in this black velvet uniform with gold braid
from cuff to elbow. And they think he's kind

1307.text:
of ridiculous. I'd like to point out there
were other generals who dressed like that.

1312.text:
They were all Southern generals. And Custer
himself, he's a product of actually border

1318.text:
state culture. He had a Maryland-born father.
He's from southern Ohio. He has very much

1322.text:
southern affinities. This is kind of the antebellum
idea of chivalry, the more Southern idea of

1332.text:
culture, again reflecting an older America,
more romantic ideal. That's the ideal that

1337.text:
Custer represents.
An interesting thing about that is that it

1341.text:
served a practical purpose. We see Custer's
affectations, it's very easy to dismiss him

1348.text:
as an egoist, someone who was full of vanity
and simply wanted everyone to look at him.

1354.text:
But on the battlefield of the Civil War, a
brigadier general is in the mix. And by drawing

1360.text:
attention to himself, he's both inspiring
his men, both giving them a rallying point.

1367.text:
They know where their commander is. He helps
to orient his men, especially when he leads

1373.text:
them forward. And it's also a declaration
about his own confidence in himself as a fighter,

1378.text:
a declaration of confidence in himself in
his own personal courage.

1382.text:
And this is something we have to remember
when we see that grand performance that Custer

1386.text:
puts on. That when it comes to battle, there's
real substance there. This is a man who actually

1392.text:
fought very well. He wasn't merely lucky.
He wasn't merely impetus. He was a real professional.

1399.text:
And in all of the chaos of Custer's life,
this is where we see him performing with confidence,

1407.text:
with self-assurance, and with real professionalism.
That's where he's in this control of himself,

1412.text:
in battle.
The problem for him is that in the future

1415.text:
of the battles come fewer and fewer, farther
and farther apart. But in the Civil War they

1420.text:
come thick and fast. His men love him. They
admire him. May be the last American general

1426.text:
to kill someone in a sword fight. And seeing
their leader actually fighting and fighting

1432.text:
well, not just bravely but with personal skill,
this is something that his men absolutely

1436.text:
loved.
One of his soldiers says, "I saw General Custer

1441.text:
plunge his saber into the belly of a rebel
trying to kill him." You can imagine how hard

1446.text:
men fight for a general who is that brave.
So this is something that can seem, you know,

1455.text:
difficult to repugnant or ridiculous to a
modern mind but to that mind that comes out

1460.text:
of antebellum America in a world in which
the Civil War is crushing gallantry, crushing

1469.text:
individual heroics, under the massive fire
power, Custer is in this little slice of the

1474.text:
Civil War. Cavalrymen fighting other cavalrymen
in which old-fashioned gallantry still serves

1480.text:
a practical purpose in which that romantic
image lives on allows him to succeed.

1487.text:
For that reason he becomes extremely popular.
He didn't just win battles. He did it in a

1491.text:
way that captures an older idea of America
that people felt was slipping away. At the

1497.text:
same time that he's leading a gallant charge
against a Confederate charge on horseback,

1501.text:
and fighting with a sword, at that very moment
Pickett was leading the mass infantry attack,

1508.text:
Confederate infantry attack on the third day
of the Battle of Gettysburg. And what happened?

1513.text:
Mass rifle fire and mass artillery fire wipe
them out. They died by the thousands. And

1519.text:
they went forward with all the traditional
marshal values, the traditional virtues. You

1526.text:
know, neatly lined up with their flags in
front of them. And they were crushed. Individual

1531.text:
heroics are being wiped out. So the Civil
War gives rise to Ambrose Bierce, one of the

1535.text:
darkest America writers who came out fighting
the Civil War convinced that death comes from

1541.text:
everyone at random, sometimes playing cruel
practical jokes on human beings. You have

1546.text:
Oliver Wendell Holmes whose idea bled out
of him through the bullet hole in the neck,

1552.text:
who comes out and becomes one the great realists
of American law. You have people who didn't

1558.text:
fight like Mark Twain and Henry Adams of which
darker, more ironic sensibility. Or Henry

1564.text:
Adams' brother, who is now forgotten but at
the time a very important 19th Century intellectual

1570.text:
who fought in the cavalry and who developed
a much darker and cynical world view as a

1576.text:
result.
But Custer is an outlier. He's a man who actually

1581.text:
has all of his illusions reinforced by the
Civil War. This is important to remember.

1587.text:
In the international Archives, by looking
beyond just the battle records, we see Custer

1592.text:
in another role, the institutional man, the
organizational man. And the record is full

1598.text:
of reprimands from his superiors, especially
General Kilpatrick. Custer, for example, would

1605.text:
go over the head of his division commander
to appeal directly to his patron. And he's

1610.text:
getting written reprimand saying you are supposed
to go through the chain of command; don't

1614.text:
go around your division commander. He loves
his old friends from West Point who are now

1619.text:
on the other side. He's constantly calling
truces to go socialize with his pals on the

1624.text:
enemy side. Kilpatrick is saying you've been
told before you are not to fraternize with

1630.text:
the enemy. They are the enemy. We are having
a war. And this is something Custer is constantly

1637.text:
being told not to do.
And this is a theme that runs throughout his

1640.text:
life. His difficulty as functioning as a member
of a hierarchal organization in a sense as

1648.text:
a member of a bureaucracy or a large institution,
dealing with chains of command, dealing with

1653.text:
the institutional requirements, being able
to manage subordinates and being able to meet

1660.text:
his duties as the required by superiors. And
that's something that comes up later on that

1665.text:
I'll get to in a moment.
He also confronts in the Civil War the true

1670.text:
meaning of the Civil War. Actually, the Battle
of Gettysburg and during the pursuit, when

1676.text:
the fighting guy's down, he goes to a contraband
camp as the Union Army called escaped slaves

1682.text:
before the Emancipation Proclamation to justify
not returning escaped slaves to Southern slaveholders.

1688.text:
They said they're contraband of war. That
became the nickname for escaped slaves, contrabands.

1693.text:
He found a young woman who was a teenager,
Eliza Brown. And Eliza Brown had worked on

1700.text:
a large farm, not quite a plantation, slave-holding
farm in Northern Virginia. She had managed

1709.text:
to work inside the master's house. She had
been a cook and domestic servant. And she

1716.text:
escaped. And Custer found her. He hired her
to be his personal cook.

1720.text:
Well, what happened is that Eliza Brown wasn't
merely a cook, wasn't merely a servant. She

1726.text:
was someone who both believed in the cause
and she said later on not everyone who fought

1732.text:
carried a musket. And she also saw the possibilities
for her as someone who had never had personal

1741.text:
safety, someone who had never had any authority
within the larger world outside of the slave

1747.text:
quarters, seizes this opportunity as the personal
servant and cook to the general who is in

1753.text:
command of her brigade. And she begins to
trade information. She literally butters up,

1759.text:
or butters up biscuits, for visitors from
higher level headquarters and squeezes information

1766.text:
out of them, which she spreads. She becomes
a figure of trust within the brigade. Soldiers

1773.text:
would come to her and leave her money and
valuables and ask her to intercede with Custer

1777.text:
for this special request. She builds her own
patronage network distributing food out of

1782.text:
the general's mess to other contrabands. This
is someone who sees an opportunity and seizes

1788.text:
it.
But what happens? Custer gets married to a

1792.text:
remarkable woman, well educated, very intelligent,
very charming woman named Libby Bacon, becomes

1802.text:
Libby Custer. And she goes to the front and
she finds there's already a woman in her husband's

1807.text:
house who is running things. Now, even though
with a cook and a servant she wasn't expected

1814.text:
to do the work, Libby was supposed to be in
charge of the domestic affairs. That's the

1817.text:
narrow slice of authority women were allowed
by 19th Century society. And she finds this

1823.text:
young black woman who has got control of it
already.

1826.text:
And Eliza Brown does not want to give up that
authority. So Eliza Brown now, her number

1831.text:
one survival adaptation in life is being able
to deal with white people who have all the

1837.text:
outward power. And she very adroitly develops
a relationship with Libby Custer where she

1845.text:
takes care of her, creates favors with her.
She builds her up as an ally and yet she very

1851.text:
adroitly keeps her out of the kitchen.
And Libby Custer in her memoirs comes up with

1856.text:
various excuses for this. You know, I didn't
know anything about dish water or the general

1861.text:
forbade me to do anything in the kitchen.
It was an attempt to explain away the fact

1867.text:
that she was being outmaneuvered by this young
black woman.

1870.text:
And over time there becomes more and more
of a power struggle. As Libby Custer realizes

1875.text:
that this narrow slice of authority is being
denied to her by a woman who is much more

1879.text:
adroit in this relationship than she is, and
the tension begins to build. That tension

1884.text:
comes to a head -- not to a final head but
it comes to an early climax in Louisiana and

1892.text:
Texas where Custer is deployed at the end
of the Civil War. He was now a national hero.

1897.text:
He had played a key role in major victories
in Virginia in 1864 and in 1865. He followed

1906.text:
Sheridan, his new patron, the commander of
the cavalry corps after Pleasanton in the

1913.text:
Army of the Potomac. And Sheridan goes to
Texas to occupy a state that had not been

1918.text:
occupied before.
Eliza Brown tries to educate the Custers about

1924.text:
the impact of slavery. She takes them into
the slave quarters. She introduces them to

1930.text:
people who got the scars of hundreds of whippings
on their back. Custer is moved by it. He has

1935.text:
a lot of respect for Libby -- for Eliza Brown.
He writes to his father-in-law, "You know,

1943.text:
the nation will always owe a debt of gratitude
to the Civil War for ending this terrible

1947.text:
scourge of slavery." And yet, when he is in
Louisiana and Texas, he feels the need to

1956.text:
cultivate the local elites. This is a man
who, again, is a product of border state culture.

1962.text:
He's a very Southern-looking man even though
he's a man of the North. He's someone who

1967.text:
has very deep, conservative ideals. He's a
Democratic Party partisan. And he's also someone

1974.text:
who yearns to be accepted by the elite, by
the people at the top of society. He craves

1980.text:
it. And who are at the top of society in the
South? Who makes a point of cultivating him?

1985.text:
It's the white planters. It's the people who
had been in charge of Texas which had never

1989.text:
been occupied by Indian troops, as I said,
during the war, has no sense that it's been

1993.text:
defeated in which slavery has grown stronger.
At the beginning of the Civil War there were

1999.text:
I think 275,000 slaves in Texas. But since
it was seen as a safe zone where Union armies

2008.text:
were not penetrating, other slave holders
sent slaves into Texas. So by the end of the

2013.text:
war the number had increased to 400,000. Slavery
grows stronger during the Civil War in Texas.

2021.text:
And this is the world Custer goes into. He's
also very skeptical of the fact that the Army

2029.text:
is now in charge of enforcing law and order
and justice in the zones that it's occupying.

2036.text:
This is an area that's held in the grasp of
war, to use the term that they used at the

2041.text:
time.
Lincoln's successor, President Andrew Johnson,

2047.text:
appointed a provisional governor, Governor
Hamilton, who writes to Custer's superior,

2056.text:
the man who is in charge of Horatio Wright,
the general who was in charge of the military

2061.text:
occupation. And he says, "There's scarcely
a day that I'm not informed of a homicide

2066.text:
committed upon a freedman. The manifestation
of a settled purpose on the part of the military

2072.text:
authorities of the government to promptly
punish such offenses by a few examples in

2077.text:
proper cases would have a most happy effect."
Again, this is from the National Archives.

2083.text:
It's almost as if he had Custer's case in
mind. Quote, it must be obvious to you, General,

2088.text:
as it is to me, that we cannot depend upon
the civil authorities of our state for some

2093.text:
time yet to deal out justice to evildoers.
So violence after emancipation is rampant

2098.text:
in Texas upon the freed people. And Custer
has one of the most egregious cases imaginable

2103.text:
on his hands, the murder of a child for the
crime of going to see her mother. Custer has

2111.text:
the boy in his custody. He thinks about it.
He thinks about his beliefs. And a man who

2117.text:
is capable of great respect across the color
line in personal relationships can't escape

2122.text:
his bigotry and his belief that the federal
government should have nothing to do with

2127.text:
it, that there is, in fact, a biological racial
hierarchy, and he lets the boy go. He turns

2135.text:
him over to the civil authorities who were
still the ones in charge during the Confederacy

2143.text:
and they, of course, immediately release the
boy.

2146.text:
It's a disheartening moment when we see Custer
plunging toward the first of the great crises

2152.text:
of his life as he goes too far with his beliefs.
He wrote to his father-in-law about this time

2161.text:
that negro troops are being mustered out rapidly.
Of course, they had been recruited by the

2165.text:
tens of thousands, hundreds of thousands,
for the Union Army. He said, and I hope will

2170.text:
continue to be mustered out until the last
of the race has laid down the musket and taken

2175.text:
up his more appropriate implement, the shovel
and hoe. There are white men who are willing

2180.text:
and anxious to fill up the Army to any limit
desired. They should get the preference. I'm

2185.text:
in favor of elevating the negro to the extent
of his capability and intelligence but in

2190.text:
making this advancement I'm opposed to doing
it by correspondingly reducing or debasing

2195.text:
any portion of the white race.
This is, of course, an argument Johnson makes

2199.text:
when he vetoes the Civil Rights Act, that
somehow it discriminates against whites.

2203.text:
"As to entrusting the negroes of the Southern
states with that sacred privilege, the right

2209.text:
of suffrage, I should soon think of elevating
an Indian chief to the Popedom of Rome." It's

2214.text:
a two-for-one racial insult if you think about
it. "All advocates of negro suffrage should

2219.text:
visit the Southern states and see the class
of people upon whom they would desire to further

2223.text:
privilege."
This is a moment when the idea of political

2228.text:
equality is being talked about in which the
14th Amendment is being drafted in which the

2236.text:
idea of not simply that African Americans
should be fee but they should be a of the

2241.text:
American policy is play and Custer is opposed
to. A lot of the Army officers felt that way.

2248.text:
If Custer had left it at that, it would have
been one thing but he didn't. He returns from

2254.text:
Texas, testifies before the joint committee
on Reconstruction, actually quite honestly

2261.text:
about the violence in Texas, inflicted upon
the freed people, about how the former Confederates

2267.text:
are not willing to surrender in spirit, even
if they have it technically. And yet he soon

2274.text:
realizes that there's a battle going on between
Republicans in Congress who want civil rights

2279.text:
legislation from President Andrew Johnson
who is increasingly opposed to it. And he

2285.text:
sides with Johnson.
And when Johnson -- when General Grant appoints

2291.text:
Custer to the -- the 9th Cavalry, one of the
new regiments of black troops in the regular

2298.text:
Army, a regiment, I should note that goes
on to have an extremely distinguished record

2303.text:
in the West and afterward in American military
history, Custer refuses. As we know from records

2310.text:
from the National Archives, he writes to President
Johnson directly over Grant's head, once again

2315.text:
skipping over the chain of command, and says
I only want to serve with white troops. Johnson

2321.text:
recognizes an ally. And Custer, a national
celebrity, joins Johnson on a grand political

2327.text:
tour called the swing around the circle in
1866. And merely -- more than merely being

2333.text:
a figurehead, he actually gives speeches.
He defends Johnson against hecklers. He fully

2339.text:
throws himself as a serving regular Army officer
into the political fray. And this is where

2344.text:
Custer becomes controversial for the first
time, not over his actions against Native-Americans

2351.text:
but, rather, his actions in the realm of race,
equality, freedom, and the consequences of

2359.text:
emancipation. That's where Americans begin
to divide over him. A man who had been a great

2363.text:
national hero and celebrity now is corned
by much of the public.

2368.text:
There's much more to it than that but that
is -- first point where we see it. Johnson,

2373.text:
the democrats are defeated. Johnson loses
his effort. And Custer goes west. He goes

2379.text:
into a personal crisis that I think is kind
of driven by this. He enters into his first

2385.text:
campaign against American Indians. And as
fascinating in many ways, one, having nothing

2392.text:
to do with Custer, is the fact that he sits
in on councils being held between General

2399.text:
Winfield Scott Hancock who leads this first
great expedition that Custer joins on the

2403.text:
Great Plains. He's conferring with Cheyennes
and the Great Plains. They're explicitly telling

2415.text:
him what the crisis is. Even before settlers
began to move in under the Great Plains and

2421.text:
occupy lands that the high plains nations
counted as their own, the migration through

2428.text:
their territory was eroding the environmental
basis for their lifestyle. Because you had

2435.text:
the California gold rush, the great migration
to Oregon, the Colorado gold rush. And you

2441.text:
had thousands of migrants moving across the
Great Plains.

2445.text:
So what do they do? They go along the river
bottoms. They follow the river valleys. Only

2451.text:
7% of the land mass -- land area of the Great
Plains. Absolutely critical to the wintering

2459.text:
of the great bison herds and also the great
horse herds that the Indians have. And it's

2465.text:
being rapidly degraded by these migrants moving
through, cut downing timber, destroying the

2470.text:
grazing, polluting the water. The Army sets
up post at the most resource-rich spots. And

2476.text:
that leads to further degradation. And they
explicitly say you're cutting down timber.

2481.text:
You're making the water unusable, etc. And
the Army doesn't understand it. And they say,

2487.text:
well, listen, you've got to let our people
move through. They're talking passed each

2491.text:
other.
So it's an interesting thing. It has nothing

2493.text:
to do with Custer's personal biography but
that you find in the National Archives the

2497.text:
records of these negotiations in their own
words and how they're talking passed each

2502.text:
other. And Custer himself doesn't quite grasp.
His first year in the Great Plains is a disaster.

2508.text:
He's, again, going through personal crisis.
He's now seen as notorious as well as a celebrity.

2514.text:
He's in a crisis with his wife. His relationship
with his wife is fascinating and complex.

2520.text:
His desire for attention from women, again
that insecurity, constantly creates crisis

2525.text:
in his marriage. He goes off and gets humiliated
by the Cheyennes on the Great Plains and he

2532.text:
finally gives up the campaign and rides back
to meet his wife and is court martialed and

2538.text:
convicted.
His wife, by the way, goes through a fascinating

2540.text:
crisis of her own when Fort Riley, where Custer
had been posted is suddenly denuded of white

2548.text:
troops and a black regiment moves in and Libby
Custer, her own memoirs, get really ugly.

2556.text:
She's terrified she's going to be raped by
a black man. And she relies upon Eliza Brown

2561.text:
to protect her. It's a really interesting,
revealing, and not very flattering picture

2567.text:
of Libby Custer both on a frontier in space
and also a frontier in time, dealing with

2574.text:
the new America in which African Americans
are playing a public role that she is not

2578.text:
prepared for. And Eliza Brown is right there
saying: What are you talking about? And, of

2583.text:
course, for her it's a great moment of finally
she's living in a black community again. She

2589.text:
has a rich social life again. And here is
her employer who is going nuts, purely out

2595.text:
of racist reaction that I think also reflects
the crisis in the marriage.

2600.text:
So you know, this is a well-known story. Custer
is convicted. The records in the National

2605.text:
Archives are very interesting. I quote from
them in that respect. But something that people

2609.text:
don't realize is that Custer was nearly court
martialed again. He couldn't accept the fact

2615.text:
that he had been convicted. This is not Custer
luck. This is not the way that he's use to

2620.text:
the being treated. Rules have always been
broken for him. He's always been able to avoid

2625.text:
the usual institutional process. And when
he's convicted, quite rightly, even though

2630.text:
he's only suspended for a year, he can't take
it. He writes a letter to the press saying

2635.text:
it's a trumped up prosecution and that everybody
agrees that he should never have been convicted.

2641.text:
So we find in the records of the National
Archives the judge advocate general writing

2645.text:
to General Grant saying, you know, everybody
believes that he should be court martialed

2650.text:
again. He's refusing to accept the validity
of the institutional process, of military

2656.text:
justice within the Army. He's lashing out.
He's brittle. He's defensive.

2661.text:
It's that insecurity in Custer that makes
a crisis worse. So Sheridan intervenes. He

2669.text:
says I know what he did is wrong. It really
offends me, too. Please don't do that. I actually

2674.text:
want him back in duty. Finally Custer gets
called back in duty to do what? Fight a battle.

2680.text:
A battle that's very controversial that I
talk about in the book. As far as Sheridan

2688.text:
is concerned, Custer fights well and he fights
this battle well. That's what saves him from

2694.text:
himself, his ability to fight, the thing that
we think of him as being so bad at.

2699.text:
Now, after the conclusion of this campaign
-- I'm going to move swiftly forward because

2704.text:
I want to have time for questions. Custer
engages in a lot of other areas that I talk

2709.text:
about in my book. He goes to Wall Street.
He spends a total of about two years in New

2714.text:
York after Civil War. He loves the cosmopolitan
center. He loves the theater. He loves literature.

2721.text:
He loves fine art. He tries to float a silver
mine that he had invested in Colorado on Wall

2728.text:
Street. He has no interest in running the
mine. Just wants to float the stock and sell

2732.text:
out and make a killing. And he does a terrible
job of it.

2736.text:
So he's a celebrity. He sees the world. He's
celebrated on Wall Street. He's treated to

2741.text:
fancy dinners. He sees the wealth. He wants
to take part in the new corporate economy.

2748.text:
But he doesn't grasp it. He can't master it.
And that's Custer living on this frontier

2754.text:
in time, wanting to engage with the new world
yet very much a man of an older world that's

2759.text:
beginning to disappear, unable to master the
way the world is changing.

2763.text:
He finds some success as a popular writer,
actually. He goes on to write articles for

2770.text:
one of the new national magazines. And he
tries to project himself as a public intellectual

2774.text:
writing about the Great Plains, its natural
history and then writes his memoir. It's a

2779.text:
very romantic style. It's very, very different
from Henry Adams who takes over the North

2785.text:
America review and gives orders that sound
like something an editor would say today.

2789.text:
Henry Adams says, you know, cut out all unnecessary
words, especially adjectives. It's like straight

2796.text:
out of, you know, your creative writing 101.
Custer meanwhile is trying to cram in as many

2801.text:
unnecessary words as possible. So you know,
he's somewhat popular but it's still outdated,

2807.text:
an older style. That's Custer, that older
sensibility.

2810.text:
Then something else happens during this hiatus
from the West. He's deployed to Kentucky.

2816.text:
When I was in the National Archives, I was
reading the post records. I saw Libby said,

2823.text:
"The 7th Cavalry was broken up and distributed
around the South to fight the Ku Klux Klan

2828.text:
but that was all in the Deep South so we didn't
have anything to do in Kentucky." Well, I

2833.text:
saw that his men were being detailed constantly,
two, three at a time, to aid the assistant

2841.text:
U.S. marshal in going on arrest raids.
I thought, what is he doing? So I asked an

2848.text:
Archivist where are the records I could find
of the U.S. marshal. He said, try archives

2853.text:
II in College Park, and look into the U.S.
attorneys records. So I looked into it and

2859.text:
I found, in fact, that there was a massive
offensive being carried out by the Department

2866.text:
of Justice which itself was new against the
Ku Klux Klan in Kentucky. In fact, Klan violence

2872.text:
in Kentucky in the early 1870s was rampant,
wife. You had a government that was not state

2877.text:
government not covered by the Reconstruction
Acts like the Deep South was. So the actual

2882.text:
-- governmental apparatus of Kentucky was
in league with the Ku Klux Klan.

2889.text:
So there's rampant violence going on, murders
taking place. And Custer wants nothing to

2894.text:
do with it. He wrote a report, a sarcastic
report. He was very unhappy at the time. He

2900.text:
was asked to report on his little post that
he commanded in Elizabethtown, Kentucky. He

2907.text:
reports on the number of rounds they have,
how often they drill, whether the new recruits

2912.text:
speak English. That is a man with a gambling
addiction. He writes, in his official report,

2922.text:
in responding to an inquiry, "Exactly what
meaning is intended to imply to the word gambling

2927.text:
which is construed differently by different
persons," he asks. "I'm at a loss to understand.

2932.text:
If by gambling the act of betting money or
risking it on games of chance are contests

2937.text:
of speed between horses, and if among games
of chance are included that usually known

2942.text:
as poker and similar games, my answer is that
so far as my knowledge and belief extend,

2949.text:
none of the officers of this command have
an addiction to gambling except the commanding

2954.text:
officer. And he is addicted to it only so
far as neither to interfere with his duties,

2960.text:
violate any rule proprietary, nor mettle with
other people's business." It's an official

2967.text:
report. It's as sarcastic as hell.
And then he goes on -- it's brittle. Again,

2972.text:
that wordy style we begin to see, that defensiveness,
that brittle report in a seas of discontent.

2980.text:
But then he includes a statement which is
explicitly directed against this duty of hunting

2984.text:
the Klu Klux Klan. He says, "The only means
and facilities for physical exercise by enlisted

2990.text:
men are those enjoyed at drill and on fatigue
duty and in escorting deputy U.S. Marshals

2996.text:
through the country of which methods I regard
the first two as highly preferable." He doesn't

3002.text:
believe the Army should be involved in any
legal matters. And he doesn't believe the

3006.text:
government should be prosecuting the Klan.
We know from other letters that he apparently

3010.text:
wrote to friends in Britain that he actually
sympathizes with the Klan. He spends a lot

3015.text:
of time, again, with the elite civilians in
Kentucky and he very much takes their side.

3023.text:
So this is a man who in the first age, sadly
truncated age of civil rights enforcement,

3030.text:
Custer opposes it. And even though that's
a view that is very popular with a large percentage

3036.text:
of Americans, it is very much the view of
an older America. And Custer is wedded to

3041.text:
it.
Lucky for him he goes off on the expedition

3045.text:
of 1873. But, again, going through the National
Archives, not just looking at this from high-profile

3052.text:
events, you see that Custer is seen as a problem
officer within the institution of the Army.

3058.text:
They talk about him as someone they can't
get along with. There's a dispute that blows

3063.text:
up over really nothing. But people are writing
about how we can't work with this guy. They

3068.text:
don't trust anything he says. It's about whether
they need more supply wagons or what not.

3072.text:
But nobody believes Custer because he's such
a problem officer in the view of the Army,

3077.text:
the institutional opinion of the Army.
He goes off on the Yellowstone expedition

3082.text:
escorting a surveying party for the Northern
Pacific Railroad, one of the second wave of

3087.text:
transcontinental railways through Lakota country.
He's got a brewing fight with his commanding

3095.text:
officer, Colonel Stanley. And Stanley's writing
about Custer's reputation and how he's living

3100.text:
up to his reputation as a problem officer.
He has Custer arrested briefly. And Stanley

3105.text:
gets drunk. And Custer is talking to a friend
of his about how he might have to arrest Stanley,

3109.text:
which would be mutiny. And there's obviously
the tension between the two is brewing to

3113.text:
a boiling point. But what happens? He has
two battles with the Sioux and performs very

3119.text:
well.
Something we have to remember when we get

3121.text:
to the Little Bighorn. He is not impetus.
He correctly reads an ambush of the kind that

3127.text:
led to the defeat by the Sioux during Red
Cloud's War. He reads it and avoids it. He

3134.text:
keeps his men well in hand. He's not reckless
and impetus. He doesn't win a crushing victory

3138.text:
in these two battles but, you know, he drives
off the Sioux in a very dangerous position

3145.text:
for himself and forms quite well. Stanley
is writing about how proud he is of Custer.

3150.text:
So once again Custer has created a crisis
for himself. Unable to work within an institution

3155.text:
of the Army, unable to catch on to the changing
times. But he has a chance to fight. And that's

3161.text:
what saves him from himself.
Well, he plunges himself into one more great

3169.text:
crisis. When there is a revolutionary election
in 1874, the Democrats come into control of

3177.text:
the House of Representatives and they do something
which may be familiar to you. They launch

3182.text:
a wave of investigations of the administration.
They call on Custer to testify. As I point

3189.text:
out, prosecutors or committee chairmen don't
call witnesses unless they know what they're

3194.text:
going to say. Somehow Custer has been in touch
with them. Custer, the partisan democrat.

3199.text:
And so Custer testifies about corruption in
the grant administration which he doesn't

3204.text:
know about personally. But he doesn't simply
do that. He goes to lunch with the Democratic

3209.text:
congressmen. He sits at their desks on the
floor of the House of Representatives, writing

3213.text:
letters to his wife on Democratic stationary.
A highprofile regular Army officer openly

3221.text:
allying himself with the political opposition
to the Commander In Chief. Something the Army

3225.text:
would not tolerate today. But Custer does
it.

3228.text:
And President Grant is a little upset about
this. And I think justifiably, actually. So

3234.text:
he says Custer cannot be the field commander
of the 7th Cavalry in an upcoming campaign

3241.text:
to drive in the Sioux so that the government
can seize control of the Black Hills. Again,

3246.text:
Custer sees his chance to save himself from
this crisis. A chance to fight, escaping him.

3253.text:
He becomes desperate. He pleads. He manages
to get General Terry, his immediate superior

3258.text:
to plead for him. And finally, reluctantly,
Grant allows him to be put back in command

3264.text:
of his troops and to go off to fight in an
attempt to save himself one last time from

3269.text:
a crisis that he's created for himself.
By that time the situation had changed. The

3275.text:
Lakotas and Cheyennes -- they are the ones
I think that deserve the credit for that victory.

3282.text:
In dismissing Custer as an arrogant fool,
we can diminish the magnitude of that victory

3288.text:
not simply in numbers but fighting skill and
the most amazing combination of tactical leadership

3295.text:
among the Lakotas especially. They defeat
Custer. Custer lost. He made mistakes. But

3302.text:
they won. And Custer rode into something he
couldn't luck his way out of and couldn't

3307.text:
outfight -- fight his way out of. And Custer's
luck finally ran out at the Little Bighorn.

3313.text:
The reason that was such an event for Americans
is not simply the scale of the defeat. That's

3318.text:
very true. Not simply that the cream of the
American Army such as it was was wiped out

3323.text:
by a bunch of preindustrial nomads, but that
it was led by this great, beloved, notorious

3332.text:
celebrity whom Americans had put so much meaning
on as they argued and fought over the nature

3338.text:
of America, over our basic values, over the
direction the country was taking. Custer symbolized

3343.text:
all of those things during his lifetime. And
then he died. And now he takes on new symbolic

3349.text:
meaning. Still as controversial as ever and
yet in that bright sunlight of Little Bighorn

3355.text:
we can forget all of the great crises that
ran through his life and all of the meaning

3360.text:
that he had for his fellow Americans and how
much his life tells us about the way our country

3364.text:
is that exists now came into being.
Thank you very much.

3373.text:
>> [Applause]
>> T.J. Stiles: If you have any questions

3379.text:
-- if you don't, I'll just keep talking for
another 15 minutes. There are two microphones

3384.text:
on the side. Please feel free to come up and
ask even if it's completely unrelated to anything

3403.text:
>> You mentioned on several occasions that Custer fought well. I had heard that he was
careless with his soldiers in battle. Is that

3413.text:
true? Have you found any evidence of that?
>> T.J. Stiles: No. I have think it was more

3417.text:
that he was careless with his soldiers out
of battle actually. In battle he was an aggressive

3423.text:
commander but he did not recklessly throw
his men's lives away.

3428.text:
And during the Civil War, remember, this is
a people's war. He fought with volunteers

3434.text:
who went off to work as they wanted to win.
When Custer was put in command from his regiment

3440.text:
took command of the division, the men wrote
things like now we can expect to win though

3446.text:
it's going to cost us. Winning requires attacking
and that's going to cost lives but they wanted

3451.text:
to win. They liked him because he won.
The situation where he actually was much less

3461.text:
loved by his men is when he's got to manage
rather than lead. And Custer actually had

3467.text:
conflict with his division commander. Kilpatrick

3474.text:

Custer's fellow brigade commanders killed

3479.text:

3490.text:

3498.text:
Army who deserted in double-digit percentages

3504.text:
skill. And there custard did not feel confident.
He was a young man who rose to high rank in

3509.text:
his 20s. He didn't have the confidence to
maintain stability and the tact required of

3518.text:
long-term management as opposed to combat
leadership. So he often lashed out with incredibly

3523.text:
harsh discipline, shaving heads, ordering
whippings which were actually illegal. It

3530.text:
was really something. His harshness toward
his men in peacetime was something that really

3537.text:
earned him a lot of controversy and I think
deservedly so.

the middle.

for a while now. You haven't shown me any

4046.text:

4056.text:
I'm desperate for you to feel that way again."
So this is a guy who all of his flaws are

4061.text:
creating crises in his marriage and yet the
letter reflects the fact that he's also emotionally

4066.text:
attuned to his wife and that, you know, he
needs her desperately. And she needs him as

4071.text:
well. There's real passion in their marriage.
And real sexual passion. There's real, you

4078.text:
know -- the letters they wrote to each other
really totally belie the stereotype of Victorian

4085.text:
ideas about sexuality and intimacy. They're
very sexually intimate. He has to reprimand

4091.text:
her during the Civil War for the letters of
double -- a couple of times his letters got

4097.text:
captured by the Confederate who had great
fun with him.

So this passion and the sensitivity they had
-- that he had toward her is the other side

4107.text:
of his personal flaws. It's why she takes
him back. That he is attuned to her. That

4114.text:
he does love her. He does need her. That he's
not just, you know, yelling at her and walking

4119.text:
away and expecting her to follow him. This
is a real emotional, complicated emotional

4125.text:
relationship between the two of them.
That was a real part of the point of writing

4130.text:
this book. With Custer, even though he's so
well written about, there's so much material

4135.text:
that really gets at his interior state and
that also bring the women in his life to the

4140.text:
foreground and the relationships with each
other. In a way that's often very difficult

4146.text:
in the 19th Century. Some women, their letters
are preserved in a lot of cases with prominent

4150.text:
men. The women, you know, they're there but
you don't know what they're thinking and writing.

4155.text:
Libby Custer is not only a good memoirist
but she saved everything. She produced volumes

4161.text:
of letters herself. So the amount of information
about them and their intimate relationship

4167.text:
and the relationship between Libby and Eliza
Brown and other people is very much a part

4171.text:
of the book.
What happens is when he dies, she finds out

4176.text:
that he left her with a $9,000 debt from his
gambling on the stock market. As I point out,

4184.text:
that's larger than the annual salaries of
the presidents of the nation's largest corporations.

4191.text:
It's a big debt. And also she has to fight
with his life insurance company because he

4197.text:
had gone out on the Great Plains at the ends
of May and he didn't pay his June premium.

4203.text:
They said, well, he didn't pay his June premium
so it's invalid. It's like, really?

4209.text:
So she has to fight and fight and get people
to compromise. She's left with barely anything

4215.text:
afterwards. There's not much of a pension.
She has to go to work as a secretary. She

4221.text:
finally gets a little bit of money from the
final settlement of her father's estate that

4226.text:
allows her to quit her job so she can write
her first volume of her memoir. It becomes

4231.text:
a bestseller of she becomes a public speaker.
She begins to do well. And then that leads

4235.text:
her to have a reunion with Eliza Brown who
she had fired out on the Great Plains when

4239.text:
she finally got fed up with the fact that
Eliza Brown outmaneuvered her for six years.

4245.text:
And her meeting with Eliza Brown is the way
I conclude the book.

4249.text:
Interestingly, her second memoir is by far
the best because it benefits from this reunion

4255.text:
in which she uses Eliza Brown's memories and
recollections to enrich her book. And Eliza

4261.text:
Brown emerges as a real full character in
that second memoir and makes it, by far, the

4266.text:
best of the three books that she wrote about
their lives together.

4270.text:
So, you know, she goes on and becomes a public
speaker and a public figure. She does much

4275.text:
more than merely protect her husband's image
which she does. And she also manages her money

4280.text:
very well. This was pointed out to me by Shirley
Lecky Reid, Libby's biography and very good

4288.text:
scholar. And she points out that Libby invested
money in real estate in Bronxville, New York,

4293.text:
a developing wealthy suburb of New York city.
She manages her money far better than the

4299.text:
men in her life had, her father, her husband.
So she ends up being quite comfortable by

4304.text:
the end of her life. Though she never remarries.
She has no children. One of the great painful

4310.text:
aspects of her life. She always wanted children.
She never had them. Historians suspect that

4317.text:
Custer himself was probably infertile because
he got gonorrhea at West Point. And then not

4323.text:
only that but they treated gonorrhea in those
days by doing things like injecting you with

4328.text:
mercury in places that have to do with reproduction.
So between the two, there's a good chance

4335.text:
that he was infertile. So she never had children.
And she's a fascinating character. Shirley

4344.text:
Lecky, the book is out under her previous
name, Shirley Lecky, really wrote a good book.

4351.text:
If you're interested in her, it's the book
to go to.
